title: (x) HomeWatch logo slab serif - Belwe {Peter Spier (self), Tim D}
content:
But I’m stumped. I thought this would be something pretty common — comes from a cheap business card. Looks a bit like a slab serif interpretation of a Goudy, but the “e” and “h” are wrong. Anyone recognize it.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20071222214548im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/weblogocropped_3869.gif)

 [‹ (x) Two wedding-style scripts - Fine Hand, Helinda Rook {Mike F, Yves}](http://web.archive.org/web/20071222214548/http:/www.typophile.com/node/35792 "Go to previous forum topic") [(x) similar to Didoni / italic typewriter font - Carousel / various alternatives {Yves, Stephen} ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20071222214548/http:/www.typophile.com/node/35673 "Go to next forum topic")
author: Peter Spier

comments.content:
Did some more digging here at home. Looks like it’s Belwe, and I’m not sure we have it at work.

Thanks for looking.

Looks Belwe-like with an alternate W

Tim

Edit: cross-post

Yeah,

I’ve substituted Sylfaen for the moment, which isn’t quite heavy enough but seems to have the correct form. Converting to outlines I can goose it, unless someone knows a better alternative for the W.
There are 2 Belwes—the original and the Letraset version.
I don’t know of a digital version without the flagged ’W’. I believe this ’W’ was created by hand by the logo designer.
